frame.name: Level_of_force_exertion
frame.definition:
<def-root>An <fen>Exerter</fen>, <fen>Action</fen>, or <fen>Force</fen> is capable of exerting or does exert a physical force at a level specified by the target. That physical force may cause deformation or breakage of, or simply motion in the receiving entity. The receiving entity is conceptually present (even if remotely), but is usually not lexically explicit. This frame covers both individual-level/static uses ("a STRONG person") as well as stage-level/dynamic uses ("a STRONG push"). However, the durative, individual-level meaning appears more frequently in the data and seems more basic.
<ex>Eugenie loved the sea and was a <t>strong</t> <fex name="Exer">swimmer</fex>.</ex>
<ex>Spartacus dealt the Roman soldier a <t>mighty</t> <fex name="Act">blow</fex>.</ex>
<ex>A <t>powerful</t> <fex name="For">force</fex> tore off the tree's branches.</ex>
<fen>Exerter</fen>, <fen>Action</fen>, and <fen>Force</fen> belong to a Core set. <ex></ex>
There are several productive metaphors covered by this frame. The first and most common is one in which social influence or control is conceptualized as the physical exertion of force. The social influence/control is more specifically a propensity to cause change in social realms such as the economic, political, militaristic, cultural, or intimate: <ex>There were theoretical limits to the <t>power</t> <fex name="Exer">of the king</fex>.</ex> <ex>Voters in the South have a <t>strong</t> <fex name="Exer">incentive</fex> to keep such Democrats in office.</ex>
Another similar metaphor is one in which psychological influence or control is understood as the physical exertion of force. The psychological influence/control includes the emotional as well: <ex><fex name="Exer">Poetic words in a text</fex> can be <m>given</m> <fex name="Deg">more</fex> <fex name="Dom">emotive</fex> <t>power</t> by using melisma.</ex> <ex>He was a <t>forceful</t> <fex name="Exer">speaker</fex>.</ex>
A third metaphor involves the amount of an entity construed as the physical force exertion of said entity. Depending on context, amount could be volume, etc. (“STRONGEST critics”; “MIGHTY uproar”).
<ex></ex>
Two related physical force dynamic frames are Level_of_force_resistance and Dynamism. This frame is distinguished from the Level_of_force_resistance frame in that it describes the level of force <m>exertion</m> instead of the level of <m>resistance</m>, and also in that there are three categories of Core FE available to the target (i.e <fen>Exerter</fen>, <fen>Action</fen>, or <fen>Force</fen>), whereas in Level_of_force_resistance there are only two Core FEs (i.e. Resisting_entity and Opposing_force). Of the latter frame's FEs, Opposing_force specifies the thing that the main entity resists to a level desginated by the target. Its parallel in Level_of_force_exertion is implied but backgrounded to the extent that it rarely appears as explicit lexical material; thus there is no corresponding Core FE.
This frame differs from Dynamism with regard to individual-level cases; targets here express the FE's <m>capability</m>. In contrast, Dynamism targets express the FE's <m>tendency</m>. For example, "a STRONG person" is generally construed as a person who is <m>capable</m> of strength, while "an ENERGETIC person" (energetic.a from the Dynamism frame) is construed as a person who <m>tends</m> to be energetic.
However, there is overlap between the two frames in stage-level cases - "a STRONG push" and "an ENERGETIC push" seem rather comparable. </def-root>

FE.name: Exerter
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Exerter</fen> that can or does exert a force of the level specified by the target.
<ex>Salesmen touted the <t>power</t> <fex name="Exer">of the engine's motor</fex>.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Force
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Force</fen> that can or does exert a force of the level specified by the target.
<ex>No one should underestimate the <t>mighty</t> <fex name="For">strength</fex> of the dung beetle.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Time
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Time</fen> during which the <fen>Exerter</fen>, <fen>Action</fen>, or <fen>Force</fen> can or does exert its force.
<ex>My quads feel particularly <t>weak</t> <fex name="Tim">after 100 squats</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Circumstances
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Circumstances</fen> under which the <fen>Exerter</fen>, <fen>Action</fen>, or <fen>Force</fen> can or does exert a force.
<ex>The winds were <t>strongest</t> <fex name="Cir">during the hurricane</fex>.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Action
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Action</fen> that can or does exert a force of the level specified by the target.
<ex>She gave him a playful, <t>weak</t> <fex name="Act">punch</fex> in the arm.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Degree
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Degree</fen> to which the <fen>Exerter</fen>, <fen>Action</fen>, or <fen>Force</fen> can or does exert a force.
<ex>After being in space for six months, his muscles were <fex name="Deg">extremely</fex> <t>weak</t>.</ex>
Where <fen>Degree</fen> is expressed by a comparative or superlative form of the target, the FE is marked on the target (as well as on the rest of the comparative/superlative expression, if present): <ex>Years of lifting had made him a <t><fex name="Deg">stronger</fex></t> man.</ex> <ex>Years of lifting had made him <t><fex name="Deg">stronger</fex></t> <fex name="Deg">than any of his peers</fex>.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Place
FE.definition: <def-root>The location where the <fen>Exerter</fen>, <fen>Action</fen>, or <fen>Force</fen> can or does exert its force. <ex>Muhammad Ali's <t>force</t> <fex name="Pla">in the ring</fex> was indisputable.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Descriptor
FE.definition:
<def-root>This FE describes the force exertion of the <fen>Exerter</fen>, <fen>Action</fen>, or <fen>Force</fen>.
<ex>Henry's <fex name="Desc">longstanding</fex> <t>powerlessness</t> against the school bully made him fearful and withdrawn.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Domain
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Domain</fen> is the field in which the <fen>Exerter</fen>, <fen>Action</fen>, or <fen>Force</fen> can or does exert its force.
<ex>The U.S. possesses great <fex name="Dom">military</fex> <t>strength</t>.</ex> </def-root>

lexUnit.name: weak.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: not (capable of) exerting great force

lexUnit.name: mighty.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: possessing great power, strength, or force

lexUnit.name: power.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: the possession of great physical strength

lexUnit.name: might.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: the possession of great power, strength, or force

lexUnit.name: strength.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: the quality or state of being strong, and/or the capability to exert great force

lexUnit.name: weakness.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: the quality or state of being weak, and/or the incapability to exert great force
